üöÄ ùêìùê¢ùê¶ùêû ùêíùêûùê´ùê¢ùêûùê¨ ùêãùêöùêßùê†ùêÆùêöùê†ùêû ùêåùê®ùêùùêûùê•ùê¨ ùê°ùêöùêØùêû ùêöùê´ùê´ùê¢ùêØùêûùêù!

Since LLMs emerged, there have been two major leaps in extending their understanding of the world‚Äôs data: vision-language models and audio-language models. We have now unlocked the third: time series, the data that powers the real world, such as vitals, prices, telemetry, grid loads, clickstreams, machine metrics, and business processes. ùêìùê¢ùê¶ùêû ùêíùêûùê´ùê¢ùêûùê¨ ùêãùêöùêßùê†ùêÆùêöùê†ùêû ùêåùê®ùêùùêûùê•ùê¨ (ùêìùêíùêãùêåùê¨) are a new class of multimodal LLMs that support reasoning over multiple time series of varying length in natural language.

Excited to share our new preprint: ‚Äúùêéùê©ùêûùêßùêìùêíùêãùêå: ùêìùê¢ùê¶ùêû ùêíùêûùê´ùê¢ùêûùê¨ ùêãùêöùêßùê†ùêÆùêöùê†ùêû ùêåùê®ùêùùêûùê•ùê¨ ùêüùê®ùê´ ùêëùêûùêöùê¨ùê®ùêßùê¢ùêßùê† ùêéùêØùêûùê´ ùêåùêÆùê•ùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêöùê´ùê¢ùêöùê≠ùêû ùêåùêûùêùùê¢ùêúùêöùê• ùêìùêûùê±ùê≠ ùêöùêßùêù ùêìùê¢ùê¶ùêû-ùêíùêûùê´ùê¢ùêûùê¨ ùêÉùêöùê≠ùêö.‚Äù

üí° Highlights
- ùêìùêíùêãùêåùê¨ can caption and reason about multiple raw time series of varying length.
- ùêèùê´ùêûùê¨ùêûùê´ùêØùêûùêù ùêãùêãùêå ùêúùêöùê©ùêöùêõùê¢ùê•ùê¢ùê≠ùê¢ùêûùê¨:¬†add additional context, background, or follow-up questions.
- ùêíùê≠ùêöùê≠ùêû-ùê®ùêü-ùê≠ùê°ùêû-ùêöùê´ùê≠ ùê´ùêûùêöùê¨ùê®ùêßùê¢ùêßùê† ùê´ùêûùê¨ùêÆùê•ùê≠ùê¨: demonstrated across diverse clinical reasoning tasks, including ECG question answering, rationales verified by medical doctors.
- ùêéùê©ùêûùêß-ùê¨ùê®ùêÆùê´ùêúùêû: code, datasets, and pretrained models are available (MIT license).

text:
5 + 1 Computer Science principles we applied to the OK GO music video (the last one is obvious) 

https://lnkd.in/dEtBsuze

I recently co-directed #OKGO‚Äôs latest video alongside Damian Kulash and Aaron Duffy 

But I‚Äôm not from the music world‚Äîactually, I have a PhD in Logic and spent years teaching Computer Science at the Universidad Complutense de Madrid.

There are core principles in Computer Science that apply just as well to 
software as they do to producing a music video. Here are five of them‚Äîplus one more that might be the most important of all:

* Single source of truth
 Everything‚Äîrobots, servo-motors, music, lighting‚Äîwas synced from one control system. When you're shooting in a single take, you need one brain. During production, everything was triggered from my laptop. All I had to do was press the spacebar.

*Open/Closed principle
 One of the most fundamental SOLID principles: the system must be open to extension, but closed to change. We were fixing and reprogramming scenes constantly adding new movements. With just two hours of shoot time left, we were still measuring mirror angles for the Body Swap scene (1‚Äô55"). We needed a super stable system. 

* Embrace Design patterns
 We built the control software using design patterns from day one‚Äîfor example, the State Pattern. Each scene was a micro-architecture, that can be sequenced transparently through the system. 

* Unit tests are your best friend
 We tested every scene over and over. If one mirror was off by just one degree, the illusion broke. Each scene could be run individually‚Äîforward, backward, at 100%, at 50% speed... The robots nailed it every time. The humans? well.. they did their best ;)

* Continuous integration
 In software, it's about merging code changes frequently. On set, it meant constantly adding and testing elements‚Äîart, tech, choreography, wardrobe, camera‚Äîall evolving in real time, all feeding into a single timeline.

+1: When nothing works‚Ä¶ just try rebooting
 We did 39 takes. 12 of them were complete. The best one was the last. When something didn‚Äôt work‚Ä¶ yes, we tried resetting.

OKGO go video was produced Andrew Geller of 1stAveMachine, with SpecialGuest SpecialGuestX |¬†SGX with 25 Universal Robots robots!

#CreativeTechnology #ComputerScienceInRealLife #OKGO #UniversalRobots #SpecialGuestX #Robotics #MusicVideo #ArtAndTech

text:
When public libraries emerged in the early 1800s, they revolutionized access to knowledge. Suddenly, learning wasn‚Äôt just for the privileged‚Äîit was a public good

Today, as AI reshapes how we live, learn, and work, we have a similar opportunity to help people everywhere build the skills and technological knowledge necessary to flourish in what OpenAI CEO Sam Altman calls the Intelligence Age

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre expanding the OpenAI Academy, which began as a series of in-person workshops for developers, into something much broader: a free online hub built to serve everyone‚Äîstudents, educators, job-seekers, nonprofit leaders, and small business owners‚Äîregardless of where they live or what language they speak

The new hub will feature an expanding library of on-demand resources, including educational materials created by partners like Common Sense Media and other tools designed to help people build AI skills at their own pace. Whether someone is a beginner learning how to harness AI for the first time or a more advanced user looking to build new applications or better integrate the technology into their work, the platform is built to provide guidance, mentoring, and hands-on expertise

We‚Äôre also continuing to grow our in-person programming through partnerships with organizations and institutions of higher learning like Georgia Institute of Technology, Miami Dade College, CareerVillage.org, OATS from AARP, the Fund for the City of New York, and others working to bring AI education directly to local communities

Last week in Pittsburgh, I met with Edward Lada, Jr., the President and CEO of Goodwill Keystone Area, which is partnering with us to develop AI training for job seekers. He summed up the vision at the heart of the OpenAI Academy‚Äîand this new hub‚Äîperfectly when he said,¬† ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just introducing new tools‚Äîwe‚Äôre opening doors"

Ed also told me about a single mom in Goodwill‚Äôs Women of Wealth program who was looking to rebuild her life‚Äîand her finances‚Äîdespite the lingering debt from a car repossession years earlier. With the help of ChatGPT, she walked into a financial counseling session prepared, informed, and confident‚Äîno longer overwhelmed, but in control of her future

The goal of the OpenAI Academy is simple: to help more people make that same leap‚Äîfrom uncertainty about where to begin with AI to the confidence and knowledge to move forward

If we get this right, we won‚Äôt just help close the AI skills gap‚Äîwe‚Äôll create new ladders of opportunity and help more people find jobs and economic mobility in our increasingly AI-powered world

Find out more about OpenAI Academy and all that it has to offer here https://lnkd.in/gtqPyu_F

text:
I remember taking a walk around my suburban town growing up. My parents received phone calls from neighbors who were concerned that I was outside walking and not at home (less than 2 miles from my house). 

It felt like a scene from  Ray Bradbury's dystopian short stories ("The Pedestrian") where people were arrested for walking due to how uncommon it was. 

That moment helped me realize how much I value walkable cities and spending time outdoors. If so much of our life is artificial and synthetic, why not prioritize experiences that are fully real?

text:
Excited to announce GR00T N1, the world‚Äôs first open foundation model for humanoid robots! We are on a mission to democratize Physical AI. The power of general robot brain, in the palm of your hand - with only 2B parameters, N1 learns from the most diverse physical action dataset ever compiled and punches above its weight: 

- Real humanoid teleoperation data.
- Large-scale simulation data: we are open-sourcing 300K+ trajectories!
- Neural trajectories: we apply SOTA video generation models to ‚Äúhallucinate‚Äù new synthetic data that features accurate physics in pixels. Using Jensen‚Äôs words, ‚Äúsystematically infinite data‚Äù!
- Latent actions: we develop novel algorithms to extract action tokens from in-the-wild human videos and neural generated videos.

GR00T N1 is a single end-to-end neural net, from photons to actions:

- Vision-Language Model (System 2) that interprets the physical world through vision and language instructions, enabling robots to reason about their environment and instructions, and plan the right actions.
- Diffusion Transformer (System 1) that ‚Äúrenders‚Äù smooth and precise motor actions at 120 Hz, executing the latent plan made by System 2. 

We deploy N1 on GR1 robot, 1X Neo robot, and a large collection of simulation benchmarks. N1 achieves up to +30% boost in diverse manipulation tasks for household and industrial settings. 

While humanoid robots are the main focus of N1, our model also supports cross-embodiment. We finetune it to work on the $110 HuggingFace LeRobot SO100 robot arm! Open robot brain runs on open hardware. Sounds just right. 

Let‚Äôs solve robotics, together, one token at a time.

text:
I'm ecstatic to share Hammon Dutra and I won 2nd place in the MultiModal AI Agents Hackathon in San Francisco in the Best Use of Agno category! 

We built Internship Hunt, an agentic tool that leverages Agno, Google's Gemini and AgentQL to find students internships and write cover letters based on their profile.

Here's how we did it: 

1. We create an applicant's profile by reading their resume and use Gemini 2.0 Flash to create STAR-styled questions that are custom for each applicant. 

2. Their profile is given to Gemini 2.0 Pro with GitHub repositories filled with internships to be matched (Any internship Repo can be added in this step)

3. We take the matched internships and use AgentQL to check if they need a cover letter, interest statement or research statement. 

4. If they do, another agent builds a custom cover letter from the candidate's profile using Gemini. 

5. All agent processes are Handled using Agno's powerful library, and we leverage their Github tool to fetch and process the internships.

The best part? We'll make this publicly available tool anyone can use that is also available in Agno's library examples for remixing.

Thanks so much Ashpreet B., Yash Pratap Solanky, Rachel Lee Nabors for your support, Saroop Bharwani, üò¥ Sam Stowers, Creators Corner for making this hackathon possible, and Nikunj K. for giving the gift of Replit that helped build this! 

Check out the Devpost here: https://lnkd.in/eQAys6h8 

P.S: You can definitely win in a hackathon on 2hrs of sleep and whilst having a fever. Dare to try!

Today, we are infusing a new force throughout the GitHub Copilot experience, elevating Copilot from a pair to peer programmer with the power of AI agents:

- GitHub Copilot Agent Mode: When you toggle on agent mode in VS Code, Copilot goes beyond your initial request, completing all necessary subtasks to ensure your primary goal is achieved. Agent mode allows Copilot to iterate on its own code, propose and guide terminal commands, and analyze and resolve run-time errors. Available today for VS Code Insiders.

- GitHub Copilot Edits: We‚Äôre also announcing the GA for Copilot Edits in VS Code. First announced at GitHub Universe, it combines the best of inline edits and chat, allowing you to make changes across multiple files by prompting in natural language. And with multi-model choice, you can choose the foundation language model that you prefer between: OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4o, o1, or o3-mini, Anthropic‚Äôs Claude 3.5 Sonnet, and now, Gemini 2.0 Flash. 

- Project Padawan: Finally, a sneak peek at our autonomous SWE agent and how we envision these types of agents will fit into the GitHub user experience. When it‚Äôs released later this year, Project Padawan will allow you to directly assign issues to GitHub Copilot ‚Äì using any of the GitHub clients ‚Äì and have it produce fully-tested pull requests. 

From code completions, chat, and multi-file edits to workspace and agents, Copilot puts the human at the center of the creative work that is software development. AI helps with the things you don‚Äôt want to do, so you have more time for the things you do.

We‚Äôre excited to get your feedback on all of the above. Because in our quest to maximize developer productivity and happiness, it‚Äôs: Do. Or do not. There is no try. ‚úåÔ∏è

text:
Our first short course with Anthropic! Building Towards Computer Use with Anthropic. This teaches you to build an LLM-based agent that uses a computer interface, by generating mouse clicks and keystrokes. Computer Use is an important, emerging capability for LLMs that will let AI agents do many more tasks than were possible before, since it lets them interact with interfaces designed for humans to use, rather than only tools that provide explicit API access. I hope you will enjoy learning about it! 

This course is taught by Anthropic's Head of Curriculum, Colt Steele. You'll learn to apply image reasoning and tool use to "use" a computer as follows: a model processes an image of the screen, analyzes it to understand what's going on, and navigates the computer via mouse clicks and keystrokes. 

This course goes through the key building blocks, and culminates in a demo of an AI assistant that uses a web browser to search for a research paper, downloads the PDF, and finally summarizes the paper for you.

In detail, you‚Äôll:
- Learn about Anthropic's family of models, when to use which one, and make API requests to Claude¬†
- Use multi-modal prompts that combine text and image content blocks, and also work with streaming responses¬†¬†
- Improve your prompting by using prompt templates, using XML to structure prompts, and providing examples¬†
- Implement prompt caching to reduce cost and latency
- Apply tool-use to build a chatbot that can call different tools to respond to queries
- See all these building blocks come together in Computer Use demo

Please sign up here: https://lnkd.in/g_s5Q_76

text:
I've been exploring ways to make Vision-Language Models (VLMs) more efficient during inference, and I came up with a simple but effective technique:¬†dynamic token selection.
Here‚Äôs the idea: instead of using the same number of tokens for every part of an image, we dynamically assign tokens based on region complexity. Why waste compute on blank spaces or redundant details when you can focus on what‚Äôs important?

For example, in this image of Manhattan, some regions are compressed significantly while others retain more detail depending on their complexity: üëá

How does it work?
1Ô∏è‚É£ Extract visual features as usual.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Measure cosine similarity between features.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Cluster similar features using DBSCAN.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Replace clusters with their means as tokens.
Check out the code in the comments!

The result? At¬†25% compression, there‚Äôs¬†almost no performance loss¬†across tasks. Even at¬†50% compression, some tasks remain viable, although others (like OCR) begin to struggle. I'll put a full evaluation plot in the comments.

This is just something I tried out while thinking about test-time compute for VLMs. It‚Äôs model-agnostic, doesn‚Äôt require retraining, and can potentially work for other modalities like video and audio.
I might write more about it in the future if we decide to do a SmolVLM paper. For now, I‚Äôve linked the full evaluation results and code in the comments.
Some related work worth exploring: VisionZip, FastV, and Feather.

Let me know what you think!

Back in eighth grade, I made a promise to myself: to win a Google hackathon after submitting to the Google Science Fair. 

It took a few years, but that dream finally became a reality a few days ago at the Google Cloud x Hack2skill's AI for Impact Hackathon! 

The holidays are a time for gratitude, and this win wouldn't be possible without the incredible support and inspiration I've received along the way. 

My journey with Padayon Ko, a platform aimed at helping Filipino students secure scholarships, began in 2019 and has evolved significantly since then.

The seeds for scaling Padayon Ko were planted during a dinner conversation with Don Mendoza and Pido Tan of the Lapu-Lapu City government. I then presented the idea to Mayor Ahong Chan. Their encouragement to expand the initiative, which is currently being adopted at my alma mater, Science and Technology Education Center (STEC) c.o. thaeney dominguito, was instrumental.

My time as a software designer at Edgur, a startup co-founded by Prof. Aboozar and Sarah, provided me with invaluable hands-on experience in software engineering and exposure to AI tools. 

Building Padayon Ko initially started as a nights&weekends project. Farza and the buildspace and Nights & Weekends community in San Francisco gave me the initial push I needed to get started. This project also wouldn't have manifested without the Google Gemini API Competition (Lloyd-Bryant üëÄ).

A huge shoutout also goes to White Brick Creative Studio, especially Stephanie and Jude for providing a space(+advice) to film.

Nickie has been my rock throughout this entire process. Thank you, love.

For the Gemini API Competition, my deepest thanks go to God for enabling me to an instrument to aid Filipino talent. To my parents, thank you for your support and for giving me the privilege to pursue my passion projects.

Red Bull¬†Basement (accelerator), where I got into the top 3 of 3500+ submissions, provided invaluable insights into the business side of things. Thank you to Carl Okpala, Yaroslava, and Dain for helping me ground my idea in realistic charts/projections. I'm taking B111 because of you guys!

Nickie, thank you again for letting me know about the AI for Impact Solution posted by AI Pilipinas Cebu, spearheaded by Jerel and Luisa. I appreciate your constant celebration of every milestone; from the top 95 to the top 10 and finally to this win.

Finally, a massive thank you to the organizers at Hack2skill and the judges (Prashanth, Wookjae, Anchit, Shilpa, Richi, Adinda, Diky, Tanya, Salomone, Ray) for your time, for giving me the space to share my vision, and for this incredible award.

text: New Year's Resolution..?

posted_at.relative: 10 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

reshared_post.text:
The secret to success?
Stop hoarding your secrets.

Many instructors, teachers, and coaches believe in holding back their best information, thinking that their 'secret techniques' are what set them apart.

This is especially common among creative professionals who think their unique tools, techniques or resources are their defining factor. 

They might show their work or briefly demonstrate their process, but they're hesitant to reveal the core of what you want to learn.

This belief, however, is misguided. When you hold back your secrets, you're also holding back the potential for deeper relationships with your audience. 

While people might get some value, they're missing out on the full extent of what you can offer.

If you're truly confident in your abilities, you'll recognize that you're more than just the sum of your techniques or resources. 

Even if others use the same tools, they can't replicate your years of experience, hard-earned lessons, and unique perspective. 

The secret sauce is you. 
Not the tools.

Sharing your knowledge doesn't diminish your value; it enhances it.

By sharing freely, you're not just helping others; you're building connections. People feel empowered by the information you provide, forming an emotional bond with you as their guide. 

This leads to the creation of a community, a fan following that can dramatically impact your future opportunities.

This is how you elevate yourself from the competition. This is how you build your personal brand.

Consider well-known chefs like Gordon Ramsay and Bobby Flay. They've built empires by sharing their culinary secrets through TV shows, cookbooks, and social media. 

Their willingness to teach has led to restaurants, product lines, and countless other opportunities. They've traded their secrets for notoriety, and it's paid off exponentially.

Your best-kept secrets are actually your best vehicle for building an audience and creating opportunities. 

By letting go of the idea that you need to safeguard your knowledge, you open yourself up to growth. 

There is no 'secret sauce' that will make you irreplaceable. It's only by sharing your best tips, techniques, tools, and resources that you can truly grow and remain relevant in your field.

In the end, the choice is yours: you can be the keeper of secrets, relatively unknown and potentially irrelevant, or you can share your knowledge, build a community, and create countless opportunities for yourself and others. 

The rising tide truly does lift all boats.

Want to be the Gordon Ramsay of your industry?

Don‚Äôt think like a designer. 
Think like a chef. 

Time to cook.

What‚Äôs your secret sauce?
What do you consider a huge time saver? 
What‚Äôs a plug-in, extensions or script you think is a game changer?

If you got value from this post, please consider reposting so that others may find it. 

Thank you 

#smallbusinesscoach #contentmarketing #smallbusinessmentor #growyourinfluence #attentioneconomy #personalbranding

text:
Documenting my journey in developing a ball-detecting robot for a soccer-playing robotics project! This project has been a fantastic learning experience, pushing me to think creatively about computer vision and robot navigation.

After hitting a snag with the initial camera setup‚Äîspent hours debugging only to realize the camera module was monochrome, not color (a valuable lesson in verifying hardware specs!)‚ÄîI shifted to an edge-detection-based algorithm. I initially experimented with the OpenMV IDE's built-in "isCircle" function, but it proved too computationally heavy for this low-power camera. Edge detection offered a much more efficient alternative. To address the challenge of tracking a moving target, I implemented a two-pronged strategy: a dead zone for positional awareness, inspired by the 8-directional pads found in video game controllers, and a vector-based system for precise directional guidance. The way that the two methods work together is very sexy.

This project has reinforced the importance of:

1/ Iterative development:¬†Testing, adapting, and refining are key.
2/ Resourcefulness:¬†Finding creative solutions when faced with constraints.
3/ Continuous learning:¬†Every challenge is an opportunity to expand my skillset.

I'm particularly proud of how the vector system dynamically adjusts to the ball's position, as you can see in the video. 

There was a bit of an "aha" moment when I realized the camera was monochrome‚Äîit forced me to a) ask for help and b) with the advice received, rethink my entire approach.

This ultimately led to a more elegant solution! 

Still some hurdles to overcome, like handling occlusions and multiple objects, but that's what makes it exciting!

 #robotics #engineering #coding #learningjourney #STEM #computervision #ardunio

This app, built for my Google Pixel Watch, uses the accelerometer to detect sneaky nail-biting moments. When it senses the motion, it gently buzzes and asks if you just bit your nails. 

Awareness is the first step after all. ü§ì‚òùÔ∏è

‚ú® Key Features:
1/ Motion Detection: Uses the accelerometer (9.8 m/s¬≤) to detect nail-biting gestures.

This project is inspired by an assignment in my neuropsychology course, where I‚Äôm exploring behavioral change. Big thanks to Prof. Randi Doyle for giving us the space to better ourselves, and for indirectly giving me the chance to (finally!) learn Android development through this project!

I was working on my software engineering assignment when I hit a roadblock: how do I systematically record user interviews without drowning in over-complicated Notion templates?

So, I made my own. A straightforward user interview template in Notion. 

Here‚Äôs the breakdown:

	‚Ä¢	Interview Stage: Early conceptualizing, mid-cycle, or late-stage refinement? Know exactly when feedback was given.

	‚Ä¢	App Version: Quick access to the exact version of the app from interview time‚Äîtaking advantage of commit history on GitHub.

	‚Ä¢	Focus Areas & Key Takeaways: Keep it simple, no fluff. Instant insights.

	‚Ä¢	Next Steps: Turn feedback into actionable tasks, because let‚Äôs be real, no one wants to sort out epics after a long meeting.

	‚Ä¢	Appendix: Got transcripts, visuals, or recordings? Put it in there.

It‚Äôs barebones but if you‚Äôre drowning in over-complicated templates, give this a shot.

Special shoutout to Dave Overton for telling me that kindness is generative. So go do something nice for someone today.

Link to the template below. üöÄ Hope it helps! https://lnkd.in/gJ4YYaw5

You know that feeling when Einstein tells you your formula is good, and he wants to use it? 

Well, I haven‚Äôt experienced that, but I‚Äôve come pretty close.

This summer, I wrote an article for the OpenAI Cookbook, contributing a code snippet that mimics ChatGPT's speech-to-text functionality. 

It‚Äôs designed for voice typing and short-term applications, eliminating storage concerns. This is made possible by using Python modules like wave, pyaudio, and tempfile.

It's open-source-esque. So, after submitting it, I was surprised to learn that Ilan Bigio, an applied AI scientist at OpenAI reviewed and approved the idea*, saying it was solid.

I‚Äôm just waiting for the merge request to be finalized, but I was so excited to help my fellow devs get started or refine their project with this code, so here it is: https://lnkd.in/g5pMHQXH.

Thanks for putting me on a platform, Jerel and AI Pilipinas Cebu!

üéôÔ∏è Using Whisper API to Transcribe Speech with Your Device Microphone üé§
by Carl Kho, our Generative AI Advocate

With do-not-disturb mode permanently on, he‚Äôs studying Computer Science across seven countries at Minerva University while convincing himself his degree holds value in the age of AI and oversaturated markets. Weave Robotics (YC S24) is making Isaac, the first personal robot that‚Äôs built for the home‚Äî and it's shipping next year.  

The average American spends 3.5 years of their life on housework (cleaning, maintenance, laundry). Weave's customers (and everyone else they've spoken to) want to reclaim that time for themselves and their loved ones.  For robots to automate much of this work, they‚Äôll need a general-purpose design; they‚Äôll have to be capable (i.e., of manipulation across a long tail of tasks), and they‚Äôll have to be safe.

Weave‚Äôs first robot, Isaac, is the first and only personal robot that meets these requirements for the home and is shipping soon. Isaac will autonomously tidy up endless messes, fold laundry, and care for your home while you‚Äôre away, and they're shipping the first 30 in the fall of 2025. 

Before this, Evan Wineland was a Lead AI PM at Apple, working on major projects like Next-Gen Siri (Apple Intelligence), large-scale on-device knowledge graphs, Communication Safety, and Focus modes. Kaan Dogrusoz also comes from Apple, where he was a manager in ML Robotics research and, before that, a staff ML researcher who shipped Double Tap on the Apple Watch. posted_at.relative: 2 years ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

reshared_post.text:
This summer, I ran my first marathon and completed a ‚Äò100 Days of Code‚Äô course.

Although the two seem nothing alike, I was constantly using lessons from one to refine my strategy for the other.

I‚Äôd hobble into my room after a long run and delete hundreds of lines of code, or finish my daily project and decide to cancel my run for that day.

Distance-running is a philosophy for many things, of which coding is no exception.

Here are 3 lessons from running miles that made me better at running code:

(1) Let the grandmas overtake you.

I did most of my runs at a snail‚Äôs pace. Often, people with strollers or speed-walkers would overtake me.

I wanted nothing more than to pick up the pace and prove how great of a runner I am. But I resisted the temptation.

I knew I‚Äôd wake up the next morning with sore joints and no desire to run. 

The same goes for learning to code. After coding for a few hours, I‚Äôd have to force myself to shut the laptop and call it a day.

Be conservative. You‚Äôre in this for the long haul.

(2) Identify the biggest shovel ‚Äì discard all teaspoons.

After watching one video about how to prepare for a marathon, I was already overwhelmed.

There are ten thousand different workouts, diets, apps, and gadgets you can try out, and some people suggest all of them.

My response to this?

Identify the shovel ‚Äì the thing that‚Äôd contribute most to achieving my goal ‚Äì and forget about the teaspoons, everything else.

For running, my shovel was ‚Äòincrease mileage by 10% per week‚Äô.

I didn‚Äôt change my diet, I bought my running shoes from a thrift store, and no matter how many influencers bought cold plunges, I settled for a shower.

For coding, my shovel was the 100 days of Code course.

People recommended other courses, textbooks, and Leetcode‚Ä¶ so so much Leetcode.

I ignored it all.

This gave me a clear path to my goal and helped me stay focused.

(3) Come on man‚Ä¶ take the stairs!

I think it‚Äôs hilarious how all distance runners try to ‚Äòstay off their feet‚Äô and avoid stairs at all costs.

They push so hard in training that they dread using their legs when going about their day.

Surely, after developing such a healthy heart and lungs, you‚Äôd want to take advantage of that?

I didn‚Äôt want to fall into this trap with coding.

So instead, I actively searched for ways I could implement code in my life.

I made:

- A website for my dad on Father‚Äôs day.¬†
- A QR-code app because I didn‚Äôt like one of QRCode Monkey‚Äôs features.¬†
- A clustering algorithm to solve a problem I had in my non-technical internship.¬†
- All sorts of other things.

As long as it‚Äôs not a skyscraper‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm taking the stairs!

Two quick notes:

1. Check out some of my projects and give me criticism/complements/questions
https://lnkd.in/gwbGFiNb

2. I‚Äôll be in Berlin next Spring, training for a marathon and half-ironman. Reach out if you‚Äôd like to get in a workout.

text:
Since announcing the acquisition over a year ago now, we‚Äôve talked a lot about what the future could look like, but we haven‚Äôt shown it.

So, we came together with Scott Belsky and the Adobe team to imagine ‚Äúwhat if ...‚Äù

We wanted to share some of our ideas with you.

1. Firefly + FigJam
What if we could go from stickies to storyboard in an instant? Today, reading user journeys can be dry and requires so much imagination; tomorrow, everyone is going to want to participate and riff on them.

2. Linked Assets
What if our worlds were all connected? We could take an asset created in Adobe Substance 3D, place it in a product mockup in Figma, and the linked asset stays up to date.

3. Multiplayer in Adobe
What if the magic of multiplayer could come to life in Adobe‚Äôs apps? For example, imagine it in 3D design ‚Äì one designer working on the model while the other adjusts lighting or texture. I know I‚Äôd learn 3D so much faster if a designer was able to be in the file with me, giving me pointers and helping me out!

4. Firefly + Figma
What if Firefly worked seamlessly with your design process in Figma? Imagine generating new backgrounds for your assets that better match the vibe of the UI, or using generative fill to extend the image to fit perfectly into your responsive designs, and having it all just‚Ä¶work.

5. Figma Prototypes + After Effects
What if you could take a working prototype of your app and drop it directly into your launch video? If you‚Äôre like us, you make changes to the product until the very last minute and stress out our friends in marketing‚Ä¶so having these auto update in the video is a game changer!

6. Theme Editor
What if your assets in Adobe and product designs in Figma shared a design system with color palettes, fonts, and more? And you could make changes to all of these with just a click of a button?¬†
¬†
Oh, and imagine all the Adobe fonts in Figma!

‚Äì
There‚Äôs so much more to dream up, and we‚Äôd love to hear your ideas, too. What are you excited about?

text:
Picture this: a warm afternoon, the sun casting its golden glow over the pavement as I perched atop my bike. A mix of excitement and nervousness churned in my stomach, but my dad was there, his reassuring presence like a safety net. He gripped the back of the seat as I wobbled into action, legs pedaling like my life depended on it. All I had to do was decide where I wanted to go, and off we went, two companions on a mission.

With every rotation of the pedals, I could feel my confidence growing. The wind rushed past, carrying with it a newfound sense of freedom. And then, the moment of truth arrived - my dad let go. It was just me, my bike, and the wide road of possibilities ahead. 

That exhilaration, that feeling of purposeful momentum, isn't confined to bike rides. This is the art of setting External Markers.* When you clearly define your goals (while allowing room for iteration), working towards them becomes clearer; your bike naturally pedals itself. 

Learning how to maneuver with and across chaos was my biggest takeaway this summer. My internship with Professor Jonathan Powers, Ph.D. at Study Kit (under Minerva University) was like that pivotal moment when my dad let go of the bike seat. Together with Outdomchakriya Soth, we designed and developed an "untraditional" education blog for the world of "untraditional" academia. 

I can't help but extend my gratitude to Professor Powers and Riya. They were not afraid to point out when I was going off-path with my design decisions. They also taught me many valuable lessons about design, communication, and teamwork. I am so grateful for their wisdom and guidance. I am also extending my gratitude to Mishaal for getting me on the team. It is exceptionally rare to see a like-minded thinker. 

Here's to setting external markers. Whether it's a bike ride or a career path, the principle remains: when you're focused, when you're intentional, amazing things unfold. I learned this firsthand, and now I'm ready to ride towards my future.

text:
You know you're deep into video game development when you see everything in real life as physics collision objects. üëæ

In my first summer internship, I developed video games as research tools to support Dr. Leanne Chukoskie, Sundararaman Rengarajan, and Dr. Anna Schwartz in their projects. It was such a privilege to work with great minds and their selfless pursuit of the greater good. 

The impact of our "collision" helped Northeastern University's ReGame-XR Lab in its mission to increase the autonomy of, and reduce stigmatization against:

1) Non-speaking individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) 

2) Teens newly diagnosed with Type one Diabetes (T1D)

Before all that, though, I was scared. I was concerned that my burnout (and the recovery process) would prevent me from making a meaningful contribution to the internship.

I was surprised to find that learning two new game engines‚ÄîUnreal Engine 5 (UE5) and Unity‚Äîwith no prior knowledge, helped me shake off my burnout. This experience honed my algorithmic thinking with Unreal Engine's Blueprints and disciplined me even further in Figma as I developed iOS front-end with Unity, leading me to create my first design library for internal use.

One of the things that helped mitigate the effects of burnout was the fact that I was working on something that I felt was meaningful and important. Something for the greater good of humankind and not just for money. Pair that with a very accommodating research lab, free food, and continuous one-to-one coaching with PhDs*, I grew. The cherry on top? The lab had strong ties with Ubisoft, which gave my team invaluable advice and feedback. 

I am deeply grateful to Ara Jung for facilitating this internship and helping me as the only international intern. I am also grateful to Uri and Shravan Dinakaran for their coaching and insights in the field of R&D. Extra especially to Uri who helped me rekindle my passion for robotics. I am also grateful to my teammates for helping me learn to collaborate. This internship has truly been an eye-opening experience for me. Additionally, thank you to the career and talent development team of Minerva University for listing this opportunity.

And of course, special thanks to Leanne for making this internship happen with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF).

I highly recommend everyone, especially my neurodivergent friends, to join this internship. Even if you have no background in coding, design, or project management, Ara will make sure you thrive like the flower you are.

I am very excited about my future internships. Perhaps one in Europe? Where I finally pursue agri-robotics. I would appreciate it if you connect me to opportunities.

<Minerva University Seoul is looking for Local Partners>

Dear LinkedIn Community,

As the Experiential Education Manager of Minerva University Seoul (hereinafter MU), I‚Äôd like your help with partnership recruitment.

As part of our global learning, MU provides its students with cultural immersion experiences. In order to do so, we have been partnering with numerous businesses, organizations, and communities in Korea.

This Fall, MU will be hosting 125 students in Seoul, between Sep and Dec. 
To make another great semester for them, we are actively looking for partners. Below are the potential interaction formats.

1. Civic Project
- This is a 2-month-long mini remote-based internship. Students engage with local orgs/companies to help resolve a challenge that the local orgs/companies face in a group of 3-5. No compensation is needed. Students devote about 40-60 hours each over the 2 months to create a deliverable that could contribute to the org/firm‚Äôs vision and objective.

2. Home Meal
- This is a meal between locals and Minerva students. Local families and individuals can invite a group of students to their house or restaurant in their neighborhood to have a meal together while enjoying a conversation regarding local cultures, personal backgrounds, etc.

3. Venue Rental
- As Minerva hosts numerous events throughout its semester, it is always helpful for us to archive free/low-cost venues. Below are the most common event types we host. If you know any venue that could accommodate the below events, please share.
- 130 people orientation

- Minerva is highly passionate about giving back to the local neighborhood. And our students love to volunteer for good causes. If any NGO/NPOs need a few extra hands, please let us know.

- Given the international, multicultural aspects of Minerva student body (49 countries are represented in this class only), accommodating various dietary restrictions/preferences can be challenging. If there is any catering service that could be accommodating, please let me know.

text:
Summer is finally here and I'm sure we're all looking forward to some much-needed relaxation on the beaches of The Philippines! üèñÔ∏è

But before you can kick back and enjoy the sun, there's the dreaded airport experience to be dealt with. As someone who loves to travel, I know how stressful it can be to navigate an airport, especially when you're running late for your (connecting) flight.

That's why I'm thrilled to share the news about a project I worked on during my time in Minerva University's Cornerstone Civic Project program. 

The program partners with local organizations to help students apply their learnings, and I was lucky enough to be part of Team Qubic, working in collaboration with Gensler, the world's number one architecture firm¬π. We were tasked to enhance the experience of the airport passengers for potential application in San Francisco Airport, their main client (not affiliated during the project).

We set out to create an indoor wayfinding tool to help passengers get to their gate quickly and easily. The goal is to reduce anxiety and minimize the risk of missed flights or extra fees. Working with my fellow Minervans Chia-Tien(Greg) Wang, Taku Kemuyama, Yerkem Shakhman, Tanatswa Julius Mangena, and Dilnaz Uasheva, we designed an app concept that would guide passengers every step of the way, from check-in to boarding.

It was a challenging project, but we were determined to make it a success. We received invaluable feedback from Professor Jonathan Powers, Ph.D. We are also indebted to Chahyung Hunt, Nick Ross, CPACC, Clara T., and the entire aviation team at Gensler for helping us fine-tune our design. Through them, we ensured that our solution met the needs of both the airport and its passengers. 

I would also like to extend my personal thanks to David Levi and Shona Kinzel for coordinating behind the scenes and for teaching me a valuable lesson.

Presenting our project at Symposium (and to the entire aviation team at Gensler) were the highlights of my time at my first year Minerva. I am grateful to have had the opportunity to work on such a meaningful project with an amazing team, and I'm excited to see how our work will impact the airport experience for travelers in the future (we will see, allegedly, by the end of 2023 üëÄ). 

"Guide passengers to their gate. Every step of the way."

text:
I just realized - I never got to share my story on how I got into Minerva University.

"Dear Carl Kho,
UBC Student Number: 55120174
We are writing to let you know the results of the 2022 UBC International Scholars awards competition.
Your award nomination was very strong and as such you have been placed on the waitlist for the International Scholars award at UBC‚Ä¶"

Engineering physics at the University of British Columbia - that was the dream. The first college application from a guy indifferent toward academics (humble brag alert!). Unfortunately, UBC put me on the waitlist due to limited government funds. Regular admission was a no-go because my family didn't have the money for it, even with my full-time job. The currency conversion was too strong.

I had to reject the admission offer myself. The scene kept on replaying in my head. That instance invalidated my life's successes. It was excruciating like a slow burn.

I'm pretty sure the faculty at STEC-SHS, my senior high school, wondered why I was requesting letters and documents for all of these other colleges - LaSalle, San Carlos, and another push for the University of Toronto. Even though I was already enrolled in a certain university in Cebu, I still pushed for a successful scholarship acceptance because I wanted to feel "intelligent" again. Admittedly, I think that's why I started "Padayon Ko," my initiative where I made a database of all ongoing scholarships to help fellow Filipinos. While I genuinely want Filipinos to open their eyes to more international opportunities, a part of me just wanted to get accepted to every scholarship I applied to for validation.

Funny enough, I never applied for a school in the United States. I just felt like the culture wouldn't fit me. Then life decided to give me one more chance. 

I remember somebody messaging me about Minerva University on the Padayon Ko Facebook page. The promise of global immersion and active learning piqued my interest, so after flushing the toilet (an important detail, I was üí©-ing at the time), I immediately got to work on my application.
I spent a lot of money on proficiency and standardized exams for other international opportunities. What surprised me at Minerva was the process: it encourages applicants to show off their individual strengths. It was the last week of the rolling application, so I submitted my application on the day of the deadline (classic). I didn't give it much thought, seeing how it was a very selective university with a 2% acceptance rate. On top of that, I already had the class schedule at a university I was enrolled in.

I vividly remember how, for some reason, I woke up at 5:00 a.m. on a random summer day. I got an email from Minerva. I didn't open it until I was with my parents. When I did, the email contained only a button linking to their website and a video of the result.

I got in.

#Filipino #StudyAbroad #Scholarship #College #SanFrancisco

text:
Immensely honored and humbled by Webflow's #SpeedBuild challenge! 

I am glad I lost this contest because it taught me hard lessons only moments like these could offer. 

In fact, getting a lot of support from IRL Figmates and Webflow folks already means a lot to me! 

As always, I am also thankful for God and the priceless support that he has given in the form of my family, friends, and educators. Grabe na jud ang gihatag ang Ginoo nako ‚Äî I hope God allocates His kindness to others as well. 

The lessons I learned? 

It‚Äôs that I cannot serve multiple masters at once like how I did back in the Philippines. Quality is directly proportional to time (not a hard rule, but applicable to my situation).

The second is to ask a lot of questions in order to really define the boundaries of an ask; assumptions really got in the way of the contest.

Lastly, it‚Äôs to not push your luck. Because of the unexpectedly large academic demand and the lack of time, preparation was limited and I only got to prepare for five out of six prompts.

Guess what happened: the unprepared prompt was chosen.

P.S: The photos were my intended designs for the other prompts! 

Nonetheless, I am still very grateful to be sharing the stage with the world‚Äôs best. 16 out of 69 (not made up promise)‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs pretty good in my book!

P.S. Sorry it took me a while to post. The academic demand was really high and exhausting, but believe me, I'm enjoying the several lessons and perspective shifts that come with it. 

Hmm, I need to treat myself to a decent meal. Know any good college-cheap eats in #SanFrancisco?

We thought previously, many years ago, that the designer should be a universal unit that can do everything. We admit we were wrong :) 

Now in our agency, there is a clear division into those who deal only with the structure and user flow of digital products, who handle concepts creation, motion design, 3D, etc.

The work of a UX designer is not visible to the average user, but finding a thoughtful designer who knows how to get at the heart of the matter, is worth a lot. After all, many designers make the user flow based on their life experiences. Thus, if a freelancer is working on a product, it should be understood that they will make the UX design based on their own user experience, which may not be that extensive. Therefore, teamwork is essential in the UX design development.

reshared_post.text:
If you're trying to find the shortest path on a map, there are better alternatives to Dijkstra's algorithm (DA). One of them is A* search, a heuristic based extension to DA and I made this visualization to compare their performance.

Let's say you're planning a road trip from Bangalore to Delhi and want to find the shortest route between these two cities. Intuitively, you know that you need to head North to get there. But DA is not guided by any sense of direction and nodes are greedily explored in order of their distance from the source node. 

As you can see from the visualization, this is like a wavefront spreading equally in all directions. The edges are colored in the order they were visited. A consequence of this approach is that even edges which take us in the wrong direction are explored - you can see that all of the roads in South India are explored.

Can this redundancy be reduced or eliminated? In some cases, yes. For instance, if we knew the exact distance from each node to the destination, we could prioritize nodes which take us closer to the target. But this is as hard as solving the original problem.

A* search circumvents this by using a heuristic - an approximation of the distance from any node to the target node. Through this approximation, exploration of edges is largely in the direction of the target node - the visualization shows a more focused search pattern resulting in fewer edges explored vs DA.

In this case, the heuristic is the straight line distance which is easy to compute if you have the x,y coordinates of each node. Can any approximation be used for A* search? No, it needs to be consistent. One way of creating heuristics is to relax constraints - knock down walls, fly over obstacles (see comments for more information).

Have you come across A* search in an algorithms class? Would love to know if you've used it for any coursework or projects! If you think someone in your network might like this visualization, please share it with them!

Map of roads obtained from - https://lnkd.in/gjaVnejS
#algorithms #cp #dsa #artificialntelligence

reshared_post.text:
Learnt something interesting on the way to airport yesterday. I took an Uber cab and was intrigued by a secondary device mounted facing front in the car. 

Cab driver was pretty friendly and told me that this is a device shipped & installed by Google street view team. It continuously captures front camera view and Google uses this to update their maps and street view. 

In return of getting the device installed and ensuring that it stays on, she is sent $40 gift card every week. I felt that to be a great setup where Google gets tremendous data for pretty low cost. I thought that she will consider this monetary reward to be the key return value. However, that was not the case. 

Twice, she was stuck in a bad situation (for instance witnessing a fight in front of her car leading to traffic backlog behind her car). Both occasions, she got a call from Google checking about her safety and getting a sense of whats happening. It might be just another data collection by Google to understand deviation from trends but it gave her a sense of being protected by Google. I learnt two things from this

1. Collecting maps data leveraging the existing cab ecosystem is a great idea to capture data at really low cost.
2. Your primary feature might get people to sign up but it is frequently a secondary feature that leads to a bigger delight  for users.  

#productmanagement #googlemaps #everydaylearning #streetview #uber

"The mass has ended; go in peace."
Zooooooom! Right after that line, I would temporarily sever ties with my family* and run straight to SM Cyberzone. You know what I'm talking about. I would visit the following stores in this exact order:
- DataBlitz

I had no money, but I also had no shame. 

I would drop dead in front of the glass where they'd display the latest NVIDIA Card and (mentally) drool all over the place. Even after I got my first PC build, I would still go to the latter stores to clickity clack my way with the displayed HyperX gear, in hopes of getting sympathy from the workers. reshared_post.text:
Why do we give unlimited sick leaves to people? We encourage our team to take care of themselves and stay healthy! No medical certificates. No paperwork. It‚Äôs been working great for 10 years now. No bureaucratic overhead. People get to rest when they need to. They come to work refreshed and ready to do their best. 

Does it get abused? No. Not really. Sometimes people get sick coz they did something like party hard all-nighter on a Sunday night and then felt unwell the following Monday (of course! Duh!). They still get the sick leave. No problem. We talk about how that‚Äôs unwise. But there‚Äôs no punishment. Because of the trust that the team gives to each person. Each one tends to do what‚Äôs best for the team and do better over time, instead of trying to cheat the system or get away with the most that they can. 

What we‚Äôve learned over 10 years is that when you trust the team to do what‚Äôs best for the team, they find ways to keep that trust. And it works great! Learn more about us ‚û°Ô∏èhttps://lnkd.in/gyDfs_N6
